text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And my recommendation to do that would be a little bit stronger if the cancer is visible – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - on the scan, especially if it has progressed. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright. Doctor: So. Uh. So, I just wrote a quick note to you that sort of says your options for your prostate cancer that is getting worse and that’s why PSA and more disease on bone scan. Okay? That’s how I made that decision. You can go with cabazitaxel chemotherapy, supportive care only. That will just keep you comfortable. Or, a clinical trial, ‘cuz again with cabazitaxel, you’re gonna get supportive care. With clinical trial, you’re gonna get supportive care. You know, we’re always here to make sure you – we keep you comfortable. Uh. The clinical trial, you would need to start the enzalutamide, then have a rising PSA Patient: Yep. Doctor: It could be as short as three weeks from now that everything works. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Okay? But again, the logistics of getting the drug, the logistics of you taking it, logistics of getting a PSA, then you coming back down here and get an ARV seven and then having a week for it to come back, it’s . Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. I’m gonna put the prescription for the enzalutamide in our pharmacy, and they’re gonna do all the work behind the scenes to find out how much it’s gonna cost ya. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Put in the grants and all that other stuff for ya, so that we can get it. Once we know it’s a go, that’s when R_ and I will be back in touch about that. Okay? But you can always back out and say, “This doesn’t make sense. I’m not ready. He’s crazy. We’re not going back to Baltimore.” All of that. Okay? Something bad could happen. You could get in a lot of pain, and they got to treat you right then and there, and this will, will slip past you. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But I hope that doesn’t happen. Patient: And even, even this treatment – is successful or just extend me for –

text: Family Member: But say if his rib spots start- causing him pain - Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Can they go in specifically with a proton or? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Would it be needed, a proton be needed, or can regular radiation take care of it? Doctor: So typically it’s just regular radiation. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
